pr_title: New baseline-class-uniqueness.lock file allows incremental adoption

timeline.message: More concise if there's only one configuration
File doesn't exist if there are no problems
Why not make it a cacheable task
Mention task name in the README

timeline.author: dansanduleac

timeline.bodyText: let's get rid of the rule
timeline.author: dansanduleac

timeline.bodyText:
I think we may want to provide a different message if new duplicates appear vs when problems are fixed, or mention here that it's dangerous to have duplicate classes on the classpath and explain why it's worth spending time to fix.
Otherwise I think folks will see "run X to update locks" and they'll ./X.
timeline.author: carterkozak

timeline.message: Might as well just store configurations
Check in an example of the lockfile

timeline.bodyText: We're losing the ability to easily verify the class uniqueness on different configurations. This could be valuable when running tests since you could inadvertently test with different classes than what exists at runtime.
timeline.author: ferozco

replies.author: iamdanfox

timeline.bodyText: you might want to copy https://github.com/palantir/metric-schema/blob/develop/gradle-metric-schema/src/main/java/com/palantir/metric/schema/gradle/MetricSchemaMarkdownPlugin.java#L46 so that ./gradlew --write-locks also updates the lockfile
timeline.author: ferozco

replies.bodyText: I was a bit torn about this, because all our other --write-locks operations are pretty fast, but this one involves actually unpacking every single jar in your classpath. On the one hand a single entrypoint is quite nice, but also I think we really want people to acknowledge these and make a conscious decision to fix or not fix.
replies.author: iamdanfox

replies.bodyText: ya fair enough, my concern is that not having it linked to --write-locks will block excavators since the lockfile will not automatically be updated
replies.author: ferozco

replies.bodyText: Ok I've just copied and pasted that in so that ./gradlew --write-locks will run it.  Will make our excavators simpler, but it might make local dev a bit slower
replies.author: iamdanfox

timeline.bodyText: shouldn't the contents only change if a dependency on the configuration changes?
timeline.author: ferozco

replies.bodyText: Configurations are not Serializable, so I can't just mark a list of them as an @Input.
replies.author: iamdanfox

replies.bodyText: you can take the configuration as an input by annotating it with @classpath
replies.author: ferozco

replies.bodyText: I think that @classpath annotation would work if I had just a single configuration, but in order to preserve the ability to analyze multiple configurations, I don't have just one single configuration here but a bunch of them?
replies.author: iamdanfox

replies.bodyText: Instead of storing a set of configurations could you create a single configuration which extends from all of the provided configurations
replies.author: ferozco

replies.bodyText: I dunno, it seems that has a slight risk of false positives... e.g. if we're analyzing two configurations foo and bar and we move a jar from foo -> bar.  In the big clobbered configuration there would be no change, but actually I would expect the lockfile to change.
replies.author: iamdanfox
